questions.question_text: Which statement is true regarding the use of user input as part of a dynamic SOQL query?

choices.D: for Account acc : [SELECT Id, Name FROM Account])
choices.C: processList([SELECT Id, Name FROM sObject WHERE Type = 'Account'])

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
"A" is the only one that could be true. It doesn't define "acc", so it could be true. "D" doesn't reference the method name.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct, tested and it gives no error
I think this is a poorly constructed question. But C makes more sense if only if it's Account instead of sObject.

comments.content: Agreed, bad question, again. SOSL always returns a list of lists even if only returning one object. I verified this.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer D, sObject is not supported on queries. the SOSL query returns a list of list of sObject so it cannot be the right answer.

comments.content:

BC is not correct answers, but there's no invocation of the processList method in D.
On the other hand, it's possible to name list as 'acc' (List<Account> acc;)

questions.question_text:
A developer needs to design a custom object that will be integrated into a back-end system.
What should the developer do to ensure good data quality and to ensure that data imports, integrations, and searches perform well? (Choose two.)

A developer encounters an error that states that the Apex heap size is exceeded.
Which technique may reduce heap size?

choices.A: Add the transient keyword to the variable definition
choices.D: Use SOQL for loops instead of standard SOQL queries
choices.B: Move the variable definition inside the scope of the function
choices.C: Use static variables instead of instance variables

discussion.content: Is the question incorrectly missing a "NOT"? A, B and D are correct.

Selected Answer: D
Best practices for running within the Apex heap size
Don't use class level variables to store a large amounts of data.
Utilize SOQL For Loops to iterate and process data from large queries.
Construct methods and loops that allow variables to go out of scope as soon as they are no longer needed.

Selected Answer: D
D is your best option to start with, but B is another. I have heard that A can be as well but I'm not entirely sure why. Reference: https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=000384468&type=1

choices.C: The "Executed Units" tab under the Execution Overview Panel
choices.D: The "Execution Tree" tab under the Stack Tree Panel
